sentences: Daniel Keith Swain, (b. August 18, 1983) known mononymously as Danny!, is an American singer-songwriter, record producer, composer and voice actor.

Swain rose to prominence shortly after his debut performance on Late Night with Jimmy Fallon, where he premiered his single "Evil"; he subsequently began a side career in voice acting, narrating the fifteenth season of ESPN's Hey Rookie, Welcome to the NFL.
Swain appeared on Sesame Street that same year.
In 2013, Ebony magazine listed Swain among other rising artists in its "Leaders of the New School" piece, calling Swain one of a handful of "innovators".
GQ praised Swain's music production as "brilliantly savvy".

Swain composed background music that has since been placed in numerous motion pictures and television programs, most notably, FOX's animated series Bob's Burgers for which Swain was awarded an Emmy plaque for his contributions to an episode that won in the Outstanding Animated Program category at the 69th Primetime Emmy Awards in 2017.
Early life ==
Swain, the only son of military parents, was born in Killeen, Texas and moved to Columbia, South Carolina, as a teenager.
He attended Richland Northeast High School and began pursuing music as a hobby during his second year.
Swain started penning his own lyrics and recorded songs as a showcase for his production.
Career ==
=== 2004–2006: Early beginnings, Charm and instrumental albums ===

sentences: After spending nearly a year networking with local artists, Swain released his debut mixtape The College Kicked-Out.
section: == Career == | === 2004–2006: Early beginnings, Charm and instrumental albums ===

sentences: The record received mixed to unfavorable reviews—an up-and-coming Charlamagne tha God was among Kicked-Out's critics, panning the mixtape on air while working as a local radio station personality—which Swain would allude to in much of his later work.
section: == Career == | === 2004–2006: Early beginnings, Charm and instrumental albums ===

sentences: Shortly after Kicked-Out's release Swain was accepted to the Savannah College of Art & Design and accordingly relocated to Savannah, Georgia.
section: == Career == | === 2004–2006: Early beginnings, Charm and instrumental albums ===

sentences: It was here that he began to work on his second project, F.O.O.D.
section: == Career == | === 2004–2006: Early beginnings, Charm and instrumental albums ===

sentences: The following year Swain officially released his third mixtape Charm, which was notable for featuring an underlying theme of escapism in its narrative of a musician who wants success in music to take him away from his day-to-day routine.
section: == Career == | === 2004–2006: Early beginnings, Charm and instrumental albums ===

sentences: During this time Swain compiled an instrumental album, Dream, Interrupted, in an effort to promote his production; within two years the sequels Dream, Fulfilled and Dream, Extinguished would also be released.
section: == Career == | === 2004–2006: Early beginnings, Charm and instrumental albums ===
== Career == | === 2007–2011: MTV, And I Love H.E.R. and Interscope era ===

sentences: 2007–2011: MTV, And I Love H.E.R. and Interscope era =
section: == Career == | === 2007–2011: MTV, And I Love H.E.R. and Interscope era ===
== Career == | === 2007–2011: MTV, And I Love H.E.R. and Interscope era ===

sentences: After Charm, Swain received his first big break when MTV played a role in securing him a recording contract with Definitive Jux, an independent music label, at the time helmed by El-P of Run the Jewels fame.
section: == Career == | === 2007–2011: MTV, And I Love H.E.R. and Interscope era ===

sentences: The record deal allowed Swain to release an album through the label, promoting it with a 12" single and accompanying music video slated for an exclusive premiere on mtvU. Though the label's involvement would not amount to a released album—only the single "Just Friends", which charted on the Billboard Hot 100—the deal did establish an ongoing relationship between Swain and MTV, which began using his music extensively in various programs.
section: == Career == | === 2007–2011: MTV, And I Love H.E.R. and Interscope era ===

sentences: Swain self-released his debut album, the faux-soundtrack And I Love H.E.R. The album was cited at the time by publications such as Pitchfork, LA Weekly and ABC News as one of the best releases of the year.
section: == Career == | === 2007–2011: MTV, And I Love H.E.R. and Interscope era ===

sentences: And I Love H.E.R. was also notable for introducing another musical direction for Swain, who was experimenting with hip house, downtempo and lounge/electronica to produce a sort of "lounge-hop" hybrid.
section: == Career == | === 2007–2011: MTV, And I Love H.E.R. and Interscope era ===

sentences: Following And I Love H.E.R.'s success, Swain completed the Where Is Danny? album.
section: == Career == | === 2007–2011: MTV, And I Love H.E.R. and Interscope era ===

sentences: Interscope Records, through its short-lived digital distribution program, distributed a revamped version of the album on iTunes.
section: == Career == | === 2007–2011: MTV, And I Love H.E.R. and Interscope era ===

== Career == | === 2012–present: Breakthrough, music licensing and The Book of Daniel ===

sentences: After the release of his third studio LP Payback, the title track of Swain's previous album was featured in a commercial for Sonos wireless speakers.
section: == Career == | === 2012–present: Breakthrough, music licensing and The Book of Daniel ===

sentences: Swain signed on as a composer for MTV's internal Hype Music label (later absorbed into Sony/ATV's Extreme Music production music library) and slowly transitioned into a producer role, landing instrumental placements with various Viacom television programming as well as commercials for Nordstrom, McDonald's, and incidental music for Bob's Burgers and its soundtrack, The Bob's Burgers Music Album.
section: == Career == | === 2012–present: Breakthrough, music licensing and The Book of Daniel ===

sentences: In 2014, Swain started working on a new album, initially titled Deliverance, but later changed to The Book Of Daniel after the book in the Bible.
section: == Career == | === 2012–present: Breakthrough, music licensing and The Book of Daniel ===

sentences: During the album's development Swain appeared in Sesame Street's "Party Bus" video, which featured an original remix of "The Wheels on the Bus" composed by Swain.
section: == Career == | === 2012–present: Breakthrough, music licensing and The Book of Daniel ===

sentences: He also began working as a voiceover artist, narrating a season of Hey Rookie, Welcome to the NFL in 2016 for ESPN.
section: == Career == | === 2012–present: Breakthrough, music licensing and The Book of Daniel ===

sentences: The following year Swain was awarded an Emmy plaque from the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences for his musical contributions to the Bob's Burgers episode "Bob Actually" (Outstanding Animated Program, 2017), composing music for three scenes.
section: == Career == | === 2012–present: Breakthrough, music licensing and The Book of Daniel ===

sentences: In 2015, a tracklist for The Book of Daniel was revealed at Swain's website.
section: == Career == | === 2012–present: Breakthrough, music licensing and The Book of Daniel ===

sentences: The album debut was announced for February 29, 2016, but it was not released.
section: == Career == | === 2012–present: Breakthrough, music licensing and The Book of Daniel ===
